sub_title: Creating positive change in water management towards a more sustainable future
summary: Basja Jantowski is an experienced consultant and manager with over 19 years’ experience in water-security, WASH, water stewardship and related sustainability topics. She brings the expertise, capacities and skills to set-up and manage teams and programs and steer them towards results. From leading business development and innovation programs, Basja brings in a broad experience working with diverse stakeholders and a large global network. Her strength lays in working with and building teams that are capable and feeling valued to work towards results. She enjoys working in strategic partnerships to support the transition towards a more sustainable, resilient and equal future.

certifications.name: Specialist Training Alliance for Water Stewardship

projects.title: Micro-finance and rainwater harvesting in Nepal
projects.description: Micro-finance for rainwater harvesting is relatively new and not practised on a large scale. Due to the use of micro-finance, there is no direct subsidy needed. The use of water from rainwater harvesting ponds combined with efficient irrigation methods will have a positive impact on the environment. It will reduce pressure on other water resource and will increase people’s self-reliance through increased food security and income generation. This combination has been piloted in 6 different villages in Nepal and has proven to be succesfull as families are able to repay the loan amount in less than 3 years.

projects.title: WASH and environmental sustainbility guide
projects.description: Are you working in Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH)? Do you want to learn more about environmentally sustainable WASH approaches? In both rural and urban contexts, the quality of life of local communities largely depends on a functioning ecosystem. Water, land and other resources are all part of a single ecosystem, whose components cannot be dealt with separately. WASH interventions always affect the ecosystem and vice versa. This is why it is important to make your WASH project environmentally sustainable.

contributors.headline: Creating positive change in water management towards a more sustainable future

Heroriëntatie bij Susanne Boom

projects.title: Mapping the water harvesting potential
projects.description: The methods to collect, store, use and re-use rainwater are easy to apply. Yet, to use these methods in a sustainable and effective way, it is important to understand exactly where Rainwater Harvesting can be applied to make full use of its potential. GIS (Geographic Information Systems) can help you identify the rainwater harvesting potential and feasibility in a specific area. For this project rainwater harvesting potential maps were made for Bukina Faso, Mali and Senegal, including a climate change scenario.

projects.title: Alliance for Water Stewardship Forum & Training in Indonesia
projects.description: Supported by Australian Water Partnership, I have organised on behalf of the Alliance for Water Stewardship (AWS) Asia-Pacific the first Indonesia Forum and Training. The goal of the Forum was to build upon interest generated with key stakeholders, create awareness on shared water challenges and opportunities in Indonesia, support further partnership-building and offer training on water stewardship. Around 45 people from Indonesia, Taiwan, Australia, New Zealand and the Netherlands participated in a Water Stewardship Forum. This was followed by a 2,5 day accredited training program attended by 22 people. I was responsible for overall management and coordination, program and content development, communication and networking.

Net Zero Specialist and Carbon Sequestration Researcher

projects.title: Sustainable landscape planning in West-Kalimantan
projects.description: The landscape in the Ketapang district of West Kalimantan, Indonesia is under severe pressure from the high density of concessions for palm oil, pulp and paper, mining, and logging. To provide a way forward, Aidenvironment is working with the Bumitama Gunajaya Agro (BGA) oil palm plantation company and IDH, the Sustainable Trade Initiative, on a project that combines wildlife protection with sustainable production. This 30 month project, which started at the end of 2016, is one of the flagship projects of the new Sustainable Landscapes cluster established at our office in Bogor in January 2017. The cluster, which consists of five consultants and three GIS staff, was set up to meet the growing demand for projects on a wide range of topics, such as corridor planning, land use planning, forest conservation and rehabilitation, smallholder development, High Carbon Stock and High Conservation Value Assessments, and waste and water management.

projects.title: Accelerating WASH through catchment planning
projects.description: From 27 – 29 of June 2016, more than 25 participants from INGOs, NGOs and governmental organizations in Nepal participated in a training called ‘Accelerating WASH through planning at local level’ in Kathmandu. Aidenvironment and HELVETAS Swiss Intercooperation Nepal facilitated this training, which was focusing on improving access to WASH through local planning. The training was part of the Nepal WASH Alliance program 2016 and funded by the WASH Alliance International. As the agenda of the WASH Alliance International is focusing on acceleration of WASH, the facilitators also targeted non-Nepal WASH Alliance organizations to participate in this training, as acceleration can only come from collaboration between different sectors and stakeholders.

contributors.headline: Creating positive change in water management towards a more sustainable future

projects.title: RAIN is GAIN - tool
projects.description: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) is gaining more and more recognition as a sustainable alternative to other water supply options. It is economically viable, socially compatible and environmentally friendly. RAIN is GAIN is a tool that shows how RWH can contribute to sustainable water supply. With this tool you can calculate the RWH potential of your area and it provides you with practical information, like technological options. This will give you practical guidance on how to integrate RWH in your project and program.

projects.title: Landuse planning "Ransdalerveld"​, "Beek"​, "Mergelland-Oost"and "Mergelland-West": planning of soil and water conservation measures at catchment level
projects.description: These four large scale planning projects included a strong component on soil and water conservation as these areas are prone to erosion and surface runoff due to more intense rainfall, increased (agricultural) development and the loess soils. Soil and water conservation measures were planned at catchment level, incorporating these measures effectively into the landscape. This included consultations with farmers, farmers cooperations, nature conservation organisations and municipalities as well as field assessments and modelling using LISEM. The project has led to the effective implementation of water buffers, grass strips, field measures like mulching, contour ploughing etc. which not only reduce runoff and erosion, but ensure farmers will have productive soils on the longer-term and municipalities have less costs for repair and reconstruction of damaged roads and houses. The combination of these different measures including the payment, management and maintenance by all actors, were strong points of these projects. Untill now over 400 water buffers have been implemented.

profile_positions.description:
•	Project leader and consultant on Third Party Supplier Compliance in palm oil in Indonesia, including contract and client management and development of quick scan and in-depth risk assessment methodology for Third Party Suppliers.
•	Program manager of the country program of the WASH Alliance International in Nepal as part of RAIN.  RAIN is a global program for the implementation, promotion and knowledge sharing on rainwater harvesting in water stressed areas (WASH Alliance International).

•	Consultant and trainer for development of a catchment plan for Oxfam Nepal focusing on soil and water conservation in flood-prone and climate-change affected areas in Nepal
•	Consultant on sustainability and delta countries in the evaluation of the Partners for Water 3 program 2010 – 2015 managed by Netherlands Water Partnership and RVO (The Netherlands Enterprise Agency), led by Berenschot 
•	Consultant for the market positioning survey of the Dutch water sector in twelve developing (Water OS) countries, responsible for Rwanda, Ethiopia and Ghana (Netherlands Water Partnership).
•	Fundraising / proposal development a.o. Netherlands Enterprise Agency (RVO), DGIS, Sustainable Trade Initiative (IDH), NICFI (Norad), DFID, USAID.
